details.title: Why Faith Transcends Knowledge
details.content: Knowledge has a limitation: it can only grasp what the intellect can contain. But G-d is infinite â€” Ein Sof â€” completely beyond any intellectual container. Faith connects the soul to G-d's essence â€” beyond all definition and revelation.

details.title: Emunah Sustains All Levels
details.content: Emunah is not merely the 'food' of simple souls who cannot understand. It is the foundation that sustains all levels of spiritual development. Even the greatest scholar's understanding rests upon the foundation of faith.

details.title: Inherited Connection
details.content: Emunah is passed down from generation to generation, rooted in the deepest part of the soul (×™×—×™×“×”). All other spiritual powers â€” intellect, emotions, action â€” rest upon this foundational bond.

details.title: The Future Elevation
details.content: In the future, what we now access through faith will become knowledge. But faith will still exist â€” operating at even higher levels. The Ein Sof can never be fully comprehended; faith will always be necessary to reach the Infinite.

details.title: Why 'Bread' of Faith?
details.content: Bread represents mature understanding â€” food that requires chewing and digestion, active participation. Matzah is a unique fusion: accessible to our understanding (bread), yet connecting us to what transcends understanding (faith). On Pesach, even our most mature consciousness is fed by faith.

details.title: The Secret of Eating
details.content: When you eat something, it becomes part of you â€” transformed into your flesh and blood. Through eating matzah, the transcendent faith is internalized. It illuminates our understanding, refines our emotions, and energizes our actions.

details.title: Guarding from Chametz
details.content: Matzah must be guarded from becoming chametz. The moment the bread 'rises' â€” the moment understanding becomes self-referential â€” the connection to transcendent faith is broken. Even 18 minutes of inattention can cause fermentation.

details.title: Tasting the Future
details.content: When we eat matzah on Pesach, we are tasting the future. We experience a foretaste of what existence will be like when faith and knowledge are unified â€” the ultimate liberation from all concealment.

blocks.label: The Danger of Chametz
blocks.english: Chametz Â· Yeshut Â· The Ego That Rises
blocks.tagline: The Zohar calls chametz ×™×¦×¨ ×”×¨×¢ and associates it with the Sitra Achara. Not because knowledge is evil â€” but because knowledge disconnected from faith 'ferments.' It becomes self-referential, feeding the ego rather than revealing G-d.

details.title: The Problem of 'Rising'
details.content: ×™×©×•×ª (yeshut) â€” a sense of independent existence, of being a 'something' separate from G-d. When the soul experiences itself thinking 'I exist, I understand, I accomplish,' this is spiritual 'fermentation.' The ego expands, claiming divine gifts as personal possessions.

details.title: Da'at's Two Directions
details.content: ×“×¢×ª (knowledge) can go two directions: Holy Da'at reveals how G-d's reality eclipses all else â†’ leads to bittul. Unholy Da'at turns inward, becoming self-referential â†’ 'I know, I understand, I grasp' â†’ creates yeshut rather than bittul.

details.content: Pesach = leaving ××¦×¨×™× (Egypt) = breaking free from ××™×¦×¨×™× (constrictions). The ultimate 'strait' is the ego. On Pesach, even a crumb is prohibited because even a trace of ego-consciousness can prevent true liberation.

details.title: Chametz After Pesach
details.content: After Pesach, chametz is permitted â€” even offered at Shavuot! This proves chametz isn't intrinsically evil. The Pesach faith prepares us for Shavuot knowledge. When properly built on faith, knowledge no longer leads to yeshut.

blocks.label: Stages of Soul Development
blocks.english: Ibur Â· Yenikah Â· Mochin Â· Gestation Â· Nursing Â· Mature Mind
blocks.tagline: Just as a human develops from fetus to infant to adult, so the soul â€” and entire spiritual worlds â€” develop through three stages. Each stage has its own way of receiving divine nourishment. ××œ×›×•×ª (and all Jewish souls) rise through these stages of consciousness.

details.title: Ibur (Gestation)
details.content: The soul is 'enclosed' within a higher level, completely dependent, without independent consciousness. Like a fetus receiving nourishment through the umbilical cord. ××œ×›×•×ª rises up and becomes enclosed within ×–×¢×™×¨ ×× ×¤×™×Ÿ, receiving from within.

details.title: Yenikah (Nursing)
details.content: The soul has 'emerged' and has some independent existence, but cannot yet understand. It receives nourishment passively â€” like an infant nursing from its mother. Malchut stands back-to-back with Z'A, receiving 'milk' â€” undigested light.

details.title: Mochin (Mature Mind)
details.content: The soul has developed its intellectual faculties and can actively comprehend divine truth. It 'eats bread' â€” solid food requiring chewing and digestion. Malchut turns face-to-face with Z'A, receiving full intellectual illumination.

details.title: Faith at Every Stage
details.content: Here's the key insight: Emunah is not just for the 'immature.' It sustains all levels â€” even the highest Mochin rests on the foundation of faith. Matzah is 'bread' (mature nourishment) yet remains 'of faith' (transcendent connection).

Jewish souls are rooted in Malchut â€” the 'food' that Malchut receives is our food as well.

details.title: Atik Yomin â€” Essential Delight
details.content: The highest level within Atzilut. Represents G-d's essential will and pleasure â€” the source of Emunah. Corresponds to ×›×ª×¨ in its most transcendent aspect. This is where the 'bread of faith' originates.

details.content: ×—×›××” (Chochmah) and ×‘×™× ×” (Binah) â€” the intellectual 'parents' of the lower Sefirot. Torah originates here. When Malchut receives from Abba/Imma, it has ××•×—×™×Ÿ â€” mature understanding.

details.title: Ze'ir Anpin â€” The Six Emotions
details.content: The configuration of six emotional Sefirot (Chesed through Yesod) that actively engages with Malchut. The seven days of Pesach correspond to Z'A's seven Middot â€” each day illuminates one emotion with the 'bread of faith.'

details.title: Malchut â€” The Receptive Vessel
details.content: ××œ×›×•×ª is called × ×§×•×“×” â€” a single point with no content of its own. It receives everything from above. Through Malchut, divine light descends to create and sustain all of Beriah, Yetzirah, and Asiyah.

details.title: The First Night â€” Pure Grace
details.content: The Exodus happened not because Israel had earned it. They had sunk to the 49th level of impurity. Yet G-d revealed Himself and redeemed them â€” pure grace, coming entirely from Above. Eating matzah that night is ×—×•×‘×” to receive this unearned gift.

details.title: Seven Days â€” The Seven Middot
details.content: Pesach lasts seven days corresponding to the seven emotional Sefirot of Z'A. Each day, the corresponding Middah receives special nourishment from the 'bread of faith.' The entire structure of Z'A must be illuminated with faith-connection.

details.title: The Three Matzot
details.content: We use three matzot at the Seder â€” corresponding to ×—×›××”, ×‘×™× ×”, ×“×¢×ª (ChaBaD). Even though matzah is 'faith,' this faith is channeled through the three intellectual faculties: nullifying wisdom, developing understanding, and integrating connection.

details.title: Yachatz â€” The Breaking
details.content: We break the middle matzah. The larger piece is hidden (afikoman) â€” representing the greater divine light that remains concealed during exile, to be revealed at redemption. The smaller piece represents what's accessible now â€” yet sufficient for the mitzvah!

items.description: The First Matzah â€” initial flash of wisdom that transcends comprehension. 'Koach Mah' â€” the power of 'what?' The bittul aspect of faith.
items.detail: When a person truly connects to Chochmah, they experience themselves as 'nothing' â€” their ego dissolves in the face of divine wisdom. This is the foundation: recognition that G-d exists and we are nothing before Him. Without this, the other levels cannot be built. Remains complete at the Seder.

items.description: The Second Matzah â€” development and expansion of the initial flash. Binah 'builds' (boneh) structures of understanding from Chochmah's raw material.
items.detail: This corresponds to faith that leads to contemplation. We don't just believe â€” we meditate on what we believe, allowing it to develop into detailed understanding. This is the broken matzah at the Seder â€” Binah 'breaks' the unified light of Chochmah into detailed components that can be comprehended.

items.description: The Third Matzah â€” connection and integration. Da'at connects knowledge to the emotions and integrates it into the whole person.
items.detail: Da'at is where the danger of chametz is greatest â€” knowledge can lead to bittul (through connecting to its source) or to yeshut (through becoming self-referential). This matzah represents Da'at in its holy form: knowledge that remains connected to faith. Remains complete at the Seder.

items.description: Enclosed within a higher level. No independent consciousness. Malchut rises and is enclosed within Ze'ir Anpin.
items.detail: Like a fetus receiving nourishment through the umbilical cord. The soul is completely dependent on its source. This corresponds to the essential life-force that emunah provides â€” the basic connection allowing the soul to exist at all.

items.description: Some independent existence, but passive reception. Malchut stands back-to-back with Z'A, receiving 'milk.'
items.detail: The infant doesn't understand what it's receiving â€” it simply absorbs nourishment. Similarly, in yenikah, the soul receives divine light but doesn't truly comprehend it. Emunah remains the underlying connection even as awareness begins to awaken.

items.description: Full intellectual faculties. Active comprehension. Malchut turns face-to-face with Z'A, receiving 'bread.'
items.detail: The soul actively comprehends divine truth, 'chewing' and 'processing' it until it becomes part of the soul's own understanding. This is why Torah is called ×œ×—× (bread). Yet even here, faith remains the foundation upon which understanding is built.

items.content: Contemplation and meditation â€” breaking down the concept. When we 'chew' the matzah spiritually, we analyze and contemplate the faith it represents.
Acceptance and internalization â€” taking it into oneself. We accept the faith and draw it into our inner consciousness.
Integration â€” letting it transform every aspect of consciousness. The faith becomes part of our spiritual substance, illuminating intellect, emotions, and actions.
The minimum olive-sized portion required for the mitzvah. Spiritually: a taste is not enough. We need to fully consume the bread of faith for it to become part of us.
Ancient of Days â€” essential divine pleasure; source of faith. The highest level, representing G-d's will and delight that transcends all comprehension.
Long/Patient Face â€” expansive will; infinite patience. Where divine will extends toward creation in a measured way.
Father/Mother (Chochmah/Binah) â€” intellectual 'parents' of lower Sefirot. Source of Torah. When Malchut receives from here, it has mochin.
Short Face (6 emotions) â€” active divine engagement with creation. The seven days of Pesach illuminate Z'A's seven Middot with the bread of faith.
Kingship/Feminine â€” receives from Z'A; source of lower worlds. Jewish souls are rooted here. Malchut's 'food' is our food.

blocks.title: The Seven Days â€” Seven Middot
blocks.intro: Each day of Pesach rectifies and illuminates one of the seven emotional Sefirot of Ze'ir Anpin:

items.content: Chesed â€” Loving-kindness. The expansive desire to give without limit.
Gevurah â€” Strength/Restraint. The power to withhold and judge appropriately.
Tiferet â€” Beauty/Harmony. The balance of chesed and gevurah in perfect synthesis.
Netzach â€” Victory/Endurance. The drive to overcome obstacles and persist.
Hod â€” Splendor/Acknowledgment. The ability to submit and accept.
Yesod â€” Foundation. The channel that transmits all the Middot to Malchut.
Malchut â€” Kingship. The receptive vessel that manifests divine presence in the world.

blocks.outro: After the seven days of Pesach, we count forty-nine days until Shavuot â€” seven weeks, corresponding to seven times seven Middot. The bread of faith is 'processed' through these 49 levels until it can be received as Torah at Sinai.

items.title: The Child's Faith
items.body: A child believes everything their parent tells them without understanding. This is not a deficiency â€” it is pure, direct trust. As they mature, understanding is built upon this faith, not replacing it. The knowledge becomes a garment for the original trust.

items.title: Bread vs. Milk
items.body: Bread requires chewing and digesting â€” active participation. Milk is received passively. The soul's development moves from passive reception (yenikah/nursing) to active comprehension (mochin/bread). Yet matzah is 'bread of faith' â€” mature understanding saturated with transcendent connection.

items.title: The Poor Man's Bread
items.body: Matzah is 'lechem oni' â€” bread of poverty. A poor person has broken pieces, not complete loaves. In galut, we receive divine light in a 'broken' form. Yet even broken bread is still bread! The breaking doesn't destroy â€” it reveals truth about our current condition.

items.title: The Hidden Afikoman
items.body: The larger piece of broken matzah is hidden away, representing the greater divine light concealed during exile. We eat it at the end â€” the 'dessert' of redemption. It teaches that the hidden portion is actually greater than what we currently see.

items.title: The Two Loaves of Shavuot
items.body: After seven weeks of refinement, we bring chametz offerings at Shavuot! The Pesach faith has rectified our vessels. Knowledge built on this foundation no longer 'ferments' into ego. The goal isn't to avoid knowledge â€” but to have knowledge saturated with faith.

items.title: The Future Revelation
items.body: 'The earth will be full of knowledge of G-d.' What we now believe, we will then know. What we now accept on faith, we will then see. Yet faith will still exist â€” operating at ever higher levels, reaching toward the truly Infinite.
